segment.source: Create a Custom Power Plan
segment.target: Create a Custom Power Plan

segment.source: Create a Custom Power Plan
segment.target: Create a Custom Power Plan

segment.source: Create a Custom Power Plan
segment.target: Create a Custom Power Plan

segment.source: A power plan is a collection of hardware and system settings that manages how computers use and conserve power.
segment.target: A power plan is a collection of hardware and system settings that manages how computers use and conserve power.

segment.source: A power plan is also known as a power scheme.
segment.target: A power plan is also known as a power scheme.

segment.source: You can create custom power plans that are optimized for specific computers.
segment.target: You can create custom power plans that are optimized for specific computers.

segment.source: By default, Windows 8 and Windows Server® 2012 include three power plans: Balanced, Power Saver, and High Performance.
segment.target: By default, Windows 8 and Windows Server® 2012 include three power plans: Balanced, Power Saver, and High Performance.

segment.source: You can customize these existing plans for your systems, create new plans that are based on the existing plans, or create a new power plan from scratch.
segment.target: You can customize these existing plans for your systems, create new plans that are based on the existing plans, or create a new power plan from scratch.

segment.source: Optimizing Windows power plans can help improve battery life.
segment.target: Optimizing Windows power plans can help improve battery life.

segment.source: However, a single poorly performing application, device, or system feature can significantly reduce battery life.
segment.target: However, a single poorly performing application, device, or system feature can significantly reduce battery life.

segment.source: For information about factors that influence battery life, see Managing Battery Life and Power Consumption Overview.
segment.target: For information about factors that influence battery life, see Managing Battery Life and Power Consumption Overview.

segment.source: In this topic
segment.target: In this topic

segment.source: Creating a customized power plan
segment.target: Creating a customized power plan

segment.source: Creating a customized power plan
segment.target: Creating a customized power plan

segment.source: Click Start, and then select Control Panel.
segment.target: Click Start, and then select Control Panel.

segment.source: Click Hardware and Sound, and then select Power Options.
segment.target: Click Hardware and Sound, and then select Power Options.

segment.source: The Power Options Control Panel opens, and the power plans appear.
segment.target: The Power Options Control Panel opens, and the power plans appear.

segment.source: Click Create a power plan.
segment.target: Click Create a power plan.

segment.source: Follow the on-screen instructions to create and customize a power plan file that is based on an existing plan.
segment.target: Follow the on-screen instructions to create and customize a power plan file that is based on an existing plan.

segment.source: Name your power plan "OutdoorPlan".
segment.target: Name your power plan "OutdoorPlan".

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: You can manage most common power plan settings through Control Panel.
segment.target: You can manage most common power plan settings through Control Panel.

segment.source: To fine-tune settings that do not appear in Control Panel, see Fine-Tune a Custom Power Plan.
segment.target: To fine-tune settings that do not appear in Control Panel, see Fine-Tune a Custom Power Plan.

segment.source: To deploy the power plan, see Set the Default Power Plan.
segment.target: To deploy the power plan, see Set the Default Power Plan.

segment.target: Listing the available power plans

segment.target: On your technician computer, at an elevated command prompt, type the following:

segment.target: The computer will return the list of available power plans.

segment.source: In the following example, these plans are Balanced, Power saver, and OutdoorPlan.
segment.target: In the following example, these plans are Balanced, Power saver, and OutdoorPlan.

segment.target: Note the GUIDs that are listed next to the power plans that you want to capture.

segment.source: Deploying a power plan
segment.target: Deploying a power plan

segment.source: After you have created power plans that work for your system, you can deploy the power plans to your destination computers.
segment.target: After you have created power plans that work for your system, you can deploy the power plans to your destination computers.

segment.source: To export the OutdoorPlan power plan that you created on your technician computer, open an elevated command prompt, and then type the following
segment.target: To export the OutdoorPlan power plan that you created on your technician computer, open an elevated command prompt, and then type the following

segment.source: This creates a new power plan file.
segment.target: This creates a new power plan file.

segment.source: To deploy the power plan, see Set the Default Power Plan.
segment.target: To deploy the power plan, see Set the Default Power Plan.
